elements.content: Two new magnetic cluster-based 3D coordination polymers consisting of μ3-oxo-centered cationic homometallic [FeIII 3O­(O2CCMe3)6]+ or neutral heterometallic [FeIII 2CoIIO­(O2CCMe3)6] coordination clusters bridged by different N,N′-donor ligands into three-dimensional networks of {[Fe3O­(O2CCMe3)6(4,4′-bpy)1.5]­(OH)·0.75­(CH2Cl2)·x(H2O)} n (1, x ≈ 8) and {[Fe2CoO­(O2CCMe3)6(bpe)0.5(pyz)]} n (2) (where 4,4′-bpy = 4,4′-bipyridine; bpe = 1,2′-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethylene; pyz = pyrazine) have been prepared under solvothermal conditions. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies reveal the existence of a 6-fold interpenetrated network with rare (8,3)-c (etc) topology for 1 and a 3-fold interpenetrated network with (10,3)-b (ths) topology for 2. The interpenetration effectively results in very low BET surface areas, and the compounds have to be regarded as nonporous. Magnetic studies of 1 and 2 point to both ferro- and antiferromagnetic intra- and intercluster exchange interactions between the isotropic FeIII and the strongly anisotropic CoII spin centers. 57Fe Mössbauer spectroscopy confirms the uniform ferric (+III) valence state in both 1 and 2, and low-temperature data for 1 point toward distinct hyperfine fields for the Fe sites.

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies reveal the existence of a 6-fold interpenetrated network with rare (8,3)-c (etc) topology for 1 and a 3-fold interpenetrated network with (10,3)-b (ths) topology for 2. The interpenetration effectively results in very low BET surface areas, and the compounds have to be regarded as nonporous. Magnetic studies of 1 and 2 point to both ferro- and antiferromagnetic intra- and intercluster exchange interactions between the isotropic FeIII and the strongly anisotropic CoII spin centers. 57Fe Mössbauer spectroscopy confirms the uniform ferric (+III) valence state in both 1 and 2, and low-temperature data for 1 point toward distinct hyperfine fields for the Fe sites.

elements.content: MOFs composed of interpenetrated (8,3)-c and (10,3)-b coordination networks based on trinuclear Fe­(III) and Fe­(III)/Co­(II) pivalate clusters and N-donor organic linkers were synthesized and characterized.
elements.clean_text: MOFs composed of interpenetrated (8,3)-c and (10,3)-b coordination networks based on trinuclear Fe(III) and Fe(III)/Co(II) pivalate clusters and N-donor organic linkers were synthesized and characterized.

elements.content: Inorganic–organic porous materials, also known as metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), have been extensively and widely investigated over the past decade as a new and promising family of porous crystalline compounds due to their outstanding properties that can be utilized and explored in different fields such as catalysis, gas and liquid storages, separation and purification, chemical sensing, and photonics. Such class of highly porous materials also shows a great potential for biomedical applications, in particular as drug storage/delivery systems. MOFs can also display interesting magnetic behaviors such as the slow magnetization relaxation characteristic of a single-molecule magnet (SMM) or single-chain magnets and long-range order effects such as canted antiferromagnetism, ferro- and ferrimagnetism, or superparamagnetism. To date, several approaches for the design and fabrication of magnetic MOFs have been introduced. Most of the magnetic MOFs reported so far were built up from mononuclear d or f metal centers linked by multidentate exoligands, mostly with O- or N-donor atoms. They have been prepared usually in “one-pot” reactions, mixing the metal salts with organic ligands in different solvents and under various synthetic conditions ranging from room temperature to hydro­(solvo)­thermal and microwave heating. The rational design of such metal–organic polymeric materials is based on a “node and spacer” approach extended by Hoskins and Robson into the realm of metal–organic compounds, crystal engineering principles, concepts of molecular and supramolecular building blocks, secondary building units, and reticular synthesis developed by the groups of Yaghi, Zaworotko, and others. This strategy is based on the assembly of molecular building blocks or presynthesized metal-containing building units with multidentate organic ligands into extended coordination networks. Although many MOFs prepared by this approach have been reported, the application of oxo-bridged polynuclear carboxylate building units of Mn and Fe metal ions with additional organic linkers for the construction of magnetic three-dimensional coordination polymers remains rarely explored. To the best of our knowledge, Christou, Tasiopoulos, and co-workers succeeded in the preparation of three-dimensional polymers with {Mn19O13} magnetic building blocks displaying SMM behavior. Using stable nitronyl nitroxide radicals, Ovcharenko et al. bridged {Mn6O2} pivalate clusters into a diamond-like network. Other efforts in the preparation of coordination polymers from μ-oxo manganese or iron polynuclear carboxylates led to the formation of 1D chains or 2D layers: chains composed of trinuclear {Mn3O}, {Fe3O}, and {Fe2MO} (M = Mn, Co, Ni), tetranuclear {Mn4O2} and {Fe4O2}, or hexanuclear {Mn6O2} and {Fe6O2} carboxylate clusters and layers that are built up from homometallic {Fe3O} or heterometallic {Fe2MO} (M = Mn, Co, Ni) trinuclear carboxylate clusters. For the first time, the combination of a hexanuclear ferric pivalate cluster, [Fe6O2(OH)2(O2CCMe3)12], with N-donor ligands in solvothermal reactions, which have been demonstrated to be the best method of synthesizing crystalline materials, resulted in the formation of MOFs, namely {[Fe3O­(O2CCMe3)6(4,4′-bpy)1.5]­(OH)·0.75­(CH2Cl2)·x­(H2O)} n (1) and {[Fe2CoO­(O2CCMe3)6(bpe)0.5(pyz)]} n (2) (where 4,4′-bpy = 4,4′-bipyridine; bpe = 1,2′-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethylene; pyz = pyrazine). Herein, we present convenient synthetic routes to three-dimensional homo- and heterometallic MOFs. We also discuss their crystal structures, thermal stability, sorption, magnetic, and Mössbauer spectroscopy properties.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Inorganic-organic porous materials, also known as metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), have been extensively and widely investigated over the past decade as a new and promising family of porous crystalline compounds due to their outstanding properties that can be utilized and explored in different fields such as catalysis, gas and liquid storages, separation and purification, chemical sensing, and photonics. Such class of highly porous materials also shows a great potential for biomedical applications, in particular as drug storage/delivery systems. MOFs can also display interesting magnetic behaviors such as the slow magnetization relaxation characteristic of a single-molecule magnet (SMM) or single-chain magnets and long-range order effects such as canted antiferromagnetism, ferro- and ferrimagnetism, or superparamagnetism. To date, several approaches for the design and fabrication of magnetic MOFs have been introduced. Most of the magnetic MOFs reported so far were built up from mononuclear d or f metal centers linked by multidentate exoligands, mostly with O- or N-donor atoms. They have been prepared usually in "one-pot" reactions, mixing the metal salts with organic ligands in different solvents and under various synthetic conditions ranging from room temperature to hydro(solvo)thermal and microwave heating. The rational design of such metal-organic polymeric materials is based on a "node and spacer" approach extended by Hoskins and Robson into the realm of metal-organic compounds, crystal engineering principles, concepts of molecular and supramolecular building blocks, secondary building units, and reticular synthesis developed by the groups of Yaghi, Zaworotko, and others. This strategy is based on the assembly of molecular building blocks or presynthesized metal-containing building units with multidentate organic ligands into extended coordination networks. Although many MOFs prepared by this approach have been reported, the application of oxo-bridged polynuclear carboxylate building units of Mn and Fe metal ions with additional organic linkers for the construction of magnetic three-dimensional coordination polymers remains rarely explored. To the best of our knowledge, Christou, Tasiopoulos, and co-workers succeeded in the preparation of three-dimensional polymers with {Mn19O13} magnetic building blocks displaying SMM behavior. Using stable nitronyl nitroxide radicals, Ovcharenko et al. bridged {Mn6O2} pivalate clusters into a diamond-like network. Other efforts in the preparation of coordination polymers from μ-oxo manganese or iron polynuclear carboxylates led to the formation of 1D chains or 2D layers: chains composed of trinuclear {Mn3O}, {Fe3O}, and {Fe2MO} (M = Mn, Co, Ni), tetranuclear {Mn4O2} and {Fe4O2}, or hexanuclear {Mn6O2} and {Fe6O2} carboxylate clusters and layers that are built up from homometallic {Fe3O} or heterometallic {Fe2MO} (M = Mn, Co, Ni) trinuclear carboxylate clusters. For the first time, the combination of a hexanuclear ferric pivalate cluster, [Fe6O2(OH)2(O2CCMe3)12], with N-donor ligands in solvothermal reactions, which have been demonstrated to be the best method of synthesizing crystalline materials, resulted in the formation of MOFs, namely {[Fe3O(O2CCMe3)6(4,4'-bpy)1.5](OH)⋅0.75(CH2Cl2)⋅x(H2O)} n  (1) and {[Fe2CoO(O2CCMe3)6(bpe)0.5(pyz)]} n  (2) (where 4,4'-bpy = 4,4'-bipyridine; bpe = 1,2'-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene; pyz = pyrazine). Herein, we present convenient synthetic routes to three-dimensional homo- and heterometallic MOFs. We also discuss their crystal structures, thermal stability, sorption, magnetic, and Mössbauer spectroscopy properties.

elements.content: All reactions were carried out under aerobic conditions using commercial grade solvents. [Fe6O2(OH)2(O2CCMe3)12] and Co­(O2CCMe3)2 were synthesized as described elsewhere. Commercially available ligands were used without further purification. Infrared spectra (4000–400 cm–1) were recorded on a PerkinElmer Spectrum One spectrometer using KBr pellets. TGA/DTA measurements were carried out with a Mettler Toledo TGA/SDTA 851 in dry N2 (60 mL min–1) at a heating rate of 10 K min–1 (Figures S4 and S5 in ). Magnetic susceptibility data were recorded using a Quantum Design MPMS-5XL SQUID magnetometer as a function of field (0.1–5.0 T) and temperature (2.0–290.0 K). Experimental data were corrected for sample holder (cylindrical PTFE capsules) and diamagnetic contributions calculated from tabulated values. BET measurements and the adsorption/desorption isotherms were carried out on BELSORP-max gas adsorption systems for N2 at 77 K and CO2 at room temperature. For preparation of the samples for BET measurements, 1 and 2 were heated to 180 (1) and 220 °C (2) and kept under vacuum overnight in the sample tubes. The size, shape, and elemental composition of the prepared crystalline material of 1 and 2 were measured by scanning electron microscopy (Hitachi S-3000 N). The elemental composition of the samples was analyzed quantitatively by a Noran SIX NSS200 dispersive X-ray detector.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Details

Materials and Methods

All reactions were carried out under aerobic conditions using commercial grade solvents. [Fe6O2(OH)2(O2CCMe3)12] and Co(O2CCMe3)2 were synthesized as described elsewhere. Commercially available ligands were used without further purification. Infrared spectra (4000-400 cm-1) were recorded on a PerkinElmer Spectrum One spectrometer using KBr pellets. TGA/DTA measurements were carried out with a Mettler Toledo TGA/SDTA 851 in dry N2 (60 mL min-1) at a heating rate of 10 K min-1 (Figures S4 and S5 in ). Magnetic susceptibility data were recorded using a Quantum Design MPMS-5XL SQUID magnetometer as a function of field (0.1-5.0 T) and temperature (2.0-290.0 K). Experimental data were corrected for sample holder (cylindrical PTFE capsules) and diamagnetic contributions calculated from tabulated values. BET measurements and the adsorption/desorption isotherms were carried out on BELSORP-max gas adsorption systems for N2 at 77 K and CO2 at room temperature. For preparation of the samples for BET measurements, 1 and 2 were heated to 180 (1) and 220 °C (2) and kept under vacuum overnight in the sample tubes. The size, shape, and elemental composition of the prepared crystalline material of 1 and 2 were measured by scanning electron microscopy (Hitachi S-3000 N). The elemental composition of the samples was analyzed quantitatively by a Noran SIX NSS200 dispersive X-ray detector.

elements.content: A constant acceleration spectrometer calibrated with α-iron foil was used in order to collect the Mössbauer room temperature spectra of 150 and 10 mg/cm2 of powders of sample 1 and 2, respectively, mixed with boron nitride. In addition, a spectrum of 1 was collected at 6 K using a Janis SH-850 closed-cycle cryostat.
elements.clean_text:
Mössbauer Spectroscopy

A constant acceleration spectrometer calibrated with α-iron foil was used in order to collect the Mössbauer room temperature spectra of 150 and 10 mg/cm2 of powders of sample 1 and 2, respectively, mixed with boron nitride. In addition, a spectrum of 1 was collected at 6 K using a Janis SH-850 closed-cycle cryostat.

elements.content: Diffraction data sets for 1 and 2 were collected on an Xcalibur E and SuperNova CCD area-detector diffractometers equipped with graphite and mirror monochromated Mo Kα radiation at 293 K for 1 and at 110 K for 2. Only low resolution data up to 1.1 Å were available for crystals of 1, and there were no “observed” reflections with I > 2σ­(I) above this limit. A low temperature experiment for 1 at 100 K resulted in a poorer data set that did not allow solving and refining the structure. The crystallographic data and a summary of the data collection and refinement are listed in Table . Data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects and absorption. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares on weighted F 2 using the SHELX suite of programs. All non-H atoms were treated anisotropically except disordered solvent O and C atoms in 1 with partial occupancy, which have been refined isotropically. Some of disordered solvent water molecules in 1 have not been localized and were removed by SQUEEZE. The tert-butyl groups of pivalate ligands in 1 and one of the bridging pyrazine molecules in 2 were found to be disordered over two positions. In both structures, tert-butyl groups show enhanced thermal motion. The hydrogen atoms in 1 and 2 were placed in calculated ideal positions and refined as riding on their respective atoms. The hydrogen atom of disordered solvent atoms have not been localized and included in the model of refinement. The assignment of metal ions as Fe and Co in the crystal structure of 2 is arbitrary; therefore each metal site was refined with 2/3 occupancy of Fe and 1/3 occupancy of Co and equal coordinates and parameters of thermal motion. The purity of the as-synthesized MOFs 1 and 2 was confirmed by matching simulated and experimental X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns (STOE Powder Diffraction System, Cu Kα radiation, see Figures S12 and S13 in ).
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Diffraction data sets for 1 and 2 were collected on an Xcalibur E and SuperNova CCD area-detector diffractometers equipped with graphite and mirror monochromated Mo Kα radiation at 293 K for 1 and at 110 K for 2. Only low resolution data up to 1.1 Å were available for crystals of 1, and there were no "observed" reflections with I > 2σ(I) above this limit. A low temperature experiment for 1 at 100 K resulted in a poorer data set that did not allow solving and refining the structure. The crystallographic data and a summary of the data collection and refinement are listed in Table . Data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects and absorption. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares on weighted F 2 using the SHELX suite of programs. All non-H atoms were treated anisotropically except disordered solvent O and C atoms in 1 with partial occupancy, which have been refined isotropically. Some of disordered solvent water molecules in 1 have not been localized and were removed by SQUEEZE. The tert-butyl groups of pivalate ligands in 1 and one of the bridging pyrazine molecules in 2 were found to be disordered over two positions. In both structures, tert-butyl groups show enhanced thermal motion. The hydrogen atoms in 1 and 2 were placed in calculated ideal positions and refined as riding on their respective atoms. The hydrogen atom of disordered solvent atoms have not been localized and included in the model of refinement. The assignment of metal ions as Fe and Co in the crystal structure of 2 is arbitrary; therefore each metal site was refined with 2/3 occupancy of Fe and 1/3 occupancy of Co and equal coordinates and parameters of thermal motion. The purity of the as-synthesized MOFs 1 and 2 was confirmed by matching simulated and experimental X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns (STOE Powder Diffraction System, Cu Kα radiation, see Figures S12 and S13 in ).

[Fe6O2(OH)2(O2CCMe3)12] (0.161 g, 0.10 mmol), s-triazine (0.032 g, 0.4 mmol), 4,4′-bipyridine (0.062 g, 0.4 mmol), and CH2Cl2 (8 mL) were placed in a sealed PTFE-lined steel autoclave and heated to 120 °C for 4 h and then slowly cooled to room temperature over 48 h. Dark-green crystals of 1 were filtered off, washed with CH2Cl2 and MeCN, and dried in air (yield 0.082 g, 38% based on Fe). Elemental analysis, found (calcd.) for 1, {[Fe3O­(O2CCMe3)6(4,4′-bpy)1.5]­(OH)·0.75­(CH2Cl2)·x(H2O)} n (x = 8), C47.75H84.5Cl1.5Fe3N3O22: C, 43.60 (43.98); H, 6.33 (6.82); N, 3.49 (3.36)%. IR data (ν/cm–1): 3084w, 2972m, 2932sh, 2872sh, 1702w, 1580vs, 1483s, 1458sh, 1427s, 1380m, 1363m, 1225m, 1069m, 1046w, 1031sh, 1013w, 938w, 897w, 865w, 815m, 787m, 730w, 634m, 605s, 572sh, 563sh, 446m.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of complexes

{[Fe3O(O2CCMe3)6(4,4'-bpy)1.5](OH)⋅0.75(CH2Cl2)⋅x(H2O)} n  (1)

[Fe6O2(OH)2(O2CCMe3)12] (0.161 g, 0.10 mmol), s-triazine (0.032 g, 0.4 mmol), 4,4'-bipyridine (0.062 g, 0.4 mmol), and CH2Cl2 (8 mL) were placed in a sealed PTFE-lined steel autoclave and heated to 120 °C for 4 h and then slowly cooled to room temperature over 48 h. Dark-green crystals of 1 were filtered off, washed with CH2Cl2 and MeCN, and dried in air (yield 0.082 g, 38% based on Fe). Elemental analysis, found (calcd.) for 1, {[Fe3O(O2CCMe3)6(4,4'-bpy)1.5](OH)⋅0.75(CH2Cl2)⋅x(H2O)} n  (x = 8), C47.75H84.5Cl1.5Fe3N3O22: C, 43.60 (43.98); H, 6.33 (6.82); N, 3.49 (3.36)%. elements.content: Both MOFs, homometallic 1 and heterometallic 2, have been synthesized under solvothermal conditions in dichloromethane solution using the hexanuclear iron cluster [Fe6O2(OH)2(O2CCMe3)12] and two different N-bridging aromatic ligands. In the synthesis of the homometallic MOF 1, s-triazine and 4,4′-bipyridine were used. Although s-triazine does not coordinate to the metal clusters, its presence is necessary for the formation of sufficiently large single crystals under these reaction conditions; without s-triazine only an amorphous precipitate is formed in an autoclave. In the case of 2, both ligands, pyrazine and 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethylene, are coordinated to metal clusters to form the 3D network. The crystals of 1 and 2 are not soluble in common organic solvents. The SEM images presented in Figures S6 and S7 in show the dimensions of the formed crystals of 1 and 2 under solvothermal heating and the crystals’ growth morphology.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthetic Strategy and Preliminary Characterization

Both MOFs, homometallic 1 and heterometallic 2, have been synthesized under solvothermal conditions in dichloromethane solution using the hexanuclear iron cluster [Fe6O2(OH)2(O2CCMe3)12] and two different N-bridging aromatic ligands. In the synthesis of the homometallic MOF 1, s-triazine and 4,4'-bipyridine were used. Although s-triazine does not coordinate to the metal clusters, its presence is necessary for the formation of sufficiently large single crystals under these reaction conditions; without s-triazine only an amorphous precipitate is formed in an autoclave. In the case of 2, both ligands, pyrazine and 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene, are coordinated to metal clusters to form the 3D network. The crystals of 1 and 2 are not soluble in common organic solvents. The SEM images presented in Figures S6 and S7 in  show the dimensions of the formed crystals of 1 and 2 under solvothermal heating and the crystals' growth morphology.

elements.content: The infrared spectra of MOFs 1 and 2 display strong and broad bands in the 1619–1580 and 1427–1416 cm–1 regions, arising from asymmetric and symmetric vibrations of the coordinated carboxylate groups of the pivalate ligands, respectively, which overlap the ν­(CN) stretching vibrations of the aromatic rings. The C–H asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations for the tert-butyl group of pivalates are observed in the range of 2972–2870 cm–1, along with a strong single band at 1483 cm–1 and a doublet at 1380–1359 cm–1, which correspond to asymmetric and symmetric bending vibrations for methyl, respectively. The presence of solvate water molecules in 1 caused the appearance of a strong absorption band around 3084 cm–1.

The C-H asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations for the tert-butyl group of pivalates are observed in the range of 2972-2870 cm-1, along with a strong single band at 1483 cm-1 and a doublet at 1380-1359 cm-1, which correspond to asymmetric and symmetric bending vibrations for methyl, respectively. elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses for the MOFs were performed in a nitrogen flux in the temperature range of 25–600 °C. The TGA data for 1 shows a first weight loss until 180 °C corresponding to the removal of 0.75 dichloromethane and eight water solvent molecules (obsd 10.5%, calcd 11.5%). On further heating, organic ligands (six pivalate and 4,4′-bipyridine) decompose in three weakly resolved steps with a total weight loss of 77.0% (calcd 74.3%). MOF 2 remains stable up to 200 °C, followed by the decomposition of metal–organic frameworks in three unidentified steps until ca. 560 °C to give the expected heterometallic oxides with a total weight loss of 84.2%.

elements.content: N2 and CO2 uptake capacities of 1 and 2 were assessed by gas adsorption measurements at 1 bar. After activation, 1 can take up 39.5 cm3(STP) g–1 of N2 at 77 K, whereas 2 can take up 30.1 cm3(STP) g–1 of N2 at 77 K (Figures S8 and S9, ). CO2 adsorption capacities at 298 K (Figures S10 and S11, ) amount to 1.2 cm3(STP) g–1 for 1 and 2.5 cm3 (STP) g–1 for 2. Overall, these values are close to the measurement error limits and indicate no significant porosity.

elements.content: The crystal structures of 1 and 2 comprise μ3-oxo-centered trinuclear [FeIII 3O­(O2CCMe3)6]+ and [FeIII 2CoIIO­(O2CCMe3)6] pivalate clusters, respectively, which serve as triconnected nodes further linked by linear exobidentate N,N′-spacer ligands into 3D networks. The metal atoms in the clusters are located at the corners of a triangle and are connected by μ3-O atoms and bridging pivalates, which is typical for μ3-oxo-centered carboxylates. Each metal site in the μ3-oxo-bridged trinuclear [M3O­(O2CCMe3)6] cluster fragment adopts a distorted-octahedral NO5 surrounding and is coordinated to the central μ3-O atom, four equatorial oxygen atoms from four bridging pivalate ligands, and nitrogen atoms of a linear spacer ligand at apical positions. Although compound 2 contains different metal ions (FeIII and CoII), all trinuclear [M3O­(O2CCMe3)6] cluster fragments in 1 and 2 may be considered as possessing local D 3h symmetry, because the ability of all three metal ions to coordinate these ligands is similar and assignment of metal ions as Fe or Co is inherently arbitrary in 2 (Table ). For both 1 and 2, the FeIII oxidation state has been confirmed by 57Fe Mössbauer spectroscopy (see below).
elements.clean_text:
Structural Characterization

The crystal structures of 1 and 2 comprise μ3-oxo-centered trinuclear [FeIII 3O(O2CCMe3)6]+ and [FeIII 2CoIIO(O2CCMe3)6] pivalate clusters, respectively, which serve as triconnected nodes further linked by linear exobidentate N,N'-spacer ligands into 3D networks. The metal atoms in the clusters are located at the corners of a triangle and are connected by μ3-O atoms and bridging pivalates, which is typical for μ3-oxo-centered carboxylates. Each metal site in the μ3-oxo-bridged trinuclear [M3O(O2CCMe3)6] cluster fragment adopts a distorted-octahedral NO5 surrounding and is coordinated to the central μ3-O atom, four equatorial oxygen atoms from four bridging pivalate ligands, and nitrogen atoms of a linear spacer ligand at apical positions. Although compound 2 contains different metal ions (FeIII and CoII), all trinuclear [M3O(O2CCMe3)6] cluster fragments in 1 and 2 may be considered as possessing local D 3h  symmetry, because the ability of all three metal ions to coordinate these ligands is similar and assignment of metal ions as Fe or Co is inherently arbitrary in 2 (Table ). For both 1 and 2, the FeIII oxidation state has been confirmed by 57Fe Mössbauer spectroscopy (see below).

Compound 1, {[Fe3O­(O2CCMe3)6(4,4′-bpy)1.5]­(OH)·0.75­(CH2Cl2)·xH2O} n , crystallizes in the hexagonal space group P6/mcc. The structure comprises two types of identical but symmetry-independent [FeIII 3O­(O2CCMe3)6]+ cluster moieties covalently cross-linked by 4,4′-bipyridine spacer ligands into a 3D cationic network, with a cluster/spacer stoichiometry of 2:3. One of the symmetry-independent trinuclear [FeIII 3O­(O2CCMe3)6] moieties resides on a mirror plane (Wyckoff letter l) and another one occupies a special position of the 6-fold inversion axis (Wyckoff letter d) thus having C s and C 3h crystallographic symmetry, respectively, and their ratio in the structure is 3:1. Neighboring 2-fold symmetry related clusters connected by 4,4′-bpy are approximately coplanar and the planes through their Fe3O cores form a dihedral angle of 6.5°, while neighboring symmetry independent clusters connected by another 4,4′-bpy ligand are mutually perpendicular. The latter pair of clusters may be regarded as a pseudo-tetrahedral four-connected binodal building block, Figure . Such building blocks constitute a rare binodal unifom (8,3)-c (etc) network, Figure a. The mutual arrangement of three-connected nodes linked by a linear spacer determines the topology of polymers (provided that all donors are coordinated and all coordination sides are filled), and the parallel location of similar [M3O­(O2CCMe3)6] clusters interconnected by the same 4,4′-bpy linear spacers results in 2D honeycomb layers. The shortest cluster···cluster separation in the net measured as a distance between μ3-O atoms equals 15.125(7) and 15.127(8) Å (Fe···Fe distances through 4,4′-bpy ligands, 11.347(2) and 11.380(3) Å) for pairs of symmetry related and symmetry independent clusters, respectively.

elements.content: The crystal structure of 1 displays a 6-fold interpenetration of networks, Figure b. Despite the high degree of interpenetration, the resulting framework still possesses porosity and reveals infinite channels along the c crystallographic axis, cylindrically shaped with a diameter of ca. 1 nm and rectangular rods of ca. 1.0 × 0.5 nm2 size, Figure . These channels are filled by hydroxide counteranions, water, and dichloromethane solvent molecules. Upon removal of neutral solvent molecules, the structure of 1 reveals a large total potential solvent area volume of 12744 Å3 (39.3%, yellow color in Figure S2, ) per unit cell volume of 32439.9 Å3, as calculated by PLATON. Because hydroxide counteranions and water molecules have not been reliably localized, we assume that each hydroxide anion, necessary for charge neutrality, occupies a volume of 40 Å3. The crystallization water content of 1, x ≈ 8, though not identified directly from the single-crystal structure, was consistently derived from both thermal and elemental analysis.

elements.content: Compound 2, [Fe2CoO­(O2CCMe3)6(bpe)0.5(pyz)] n , crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c and exhibits a 3D network composed of trinuclear [FeIII 2CoIIO­(O2CCMe3)6] clusters linked by pyrazine (pyz), and 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethylene (bpe) linear spacer ligands. The atoms of the cluster moiety lie on general positions; thus all the metal atoms are symmetry-independent. Each cluster is connected with two coplanar clusters by centrosymmetric pyz and bpe ligands and one noncoplanar cluster via another pyz ligand. The latter resides on a 2-fold axis and is disordered over two symmetry related positions with equal probability. The dihedral angle between the planes through their Fe2CoO cores of adjacent 2-fold related cluster equals 71.8°. This couple of adjacent nonparallel clusters may be regarded as a four-connected unit with a nonplanar connectivity, Figure , but in contrast to 1, it is composed of symmetry related nodes and different spacer ligands, which differ in their length. The resulting network has an uniform uninodal (10,3)-b (ths) topology, Figure . The cluster···cluster separation through pyz ligands equals 10.899(4) and 10.902(4) Å for pairs of parallel and nonparallel clusters, respectively, and 17.254(3) Å through the bpe ligand, and corresponding Fe/Co···Fe/Co distances are 7.096(1), 7.142(1), and 13.603(1) Å, respectively. The crystal structure of 2 comprises 3-fold interpenetrated networks, which create voids with an individual volume of 191 Å3, Figure S3, . The total potential solvent area volume is 2204.1 Å3 (19.1%) per unit cell volume of 11547.4 Å3.

elements.content: Whereas the high-spin FeIII (3d5) centers in their octahedral environments in both 1 and 2 are characterized by an orbital singlet ground state 6A1(S), thus representing near-ideal pure spin systems, the high-spin CoII (3d7) centers in 2 are strongly influenced by orbital momentum contributions in the 4T1(F) ground state that in addition interacts with an excited 4T1(P) term. Thus, the following single-ion effects for Co­(II) were evaluated in modeling the magnetic susceptibility data using the computational framework CONDON: interelectronic repulsion, spin–orbit coupling, ligand field effect, and the Zeeman effect of an external magnetic field. The ligand field operator, reference to the 4-fold rotation axis for the angular part of the wave function assuming D 4h symmetry, reads Ĥ lf = B 0 2 ∑ i = 1 N C 0 2 ( i ) + B 0 4 ∑ i = 1 N C 0 4 ( i ) + B 4 4 ∑ i = 1 N ( C 4 4 ( i ) + C − 4 4 ( i ) ) All intracluster couplings are described by a Heisenberg-type exchange Hamiltonian, assuming an isosceles spin triangle: Ĥ ex = − 2 J 1 ( Ŝ 1 · Ŝ 2 + Ŝ 2 · Ŝ 3 ) − 2 J 2 Ŝ 1 · Ŝ 3 Intercluster interactions are taken into account by the molecular field approximation, expressed as χm –1 = χm′–1 – λmf where χm′ denotes the molar susceptibility of a discrete {M3} spin cluster and λmf the molecular field parameter.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetochemical Analysis

Whereas the high-spin FeIII (3d5) centers in their octahedral environments in both 1 and 2 are characterized by an orbital singlet ground state 6A1(S), thus representing near-ideal pure spin systems, the high-spin CoII (3d7) centers in 2 are strongly influenced by orbital momentum contributions in the 4T1(F) ground state that in addition interacts with an excited 4T1(P) term. Thus, the following single-ion effects for Co(II) were evaluated in modeling the magnetic susceptibility data using the computational framework CONDON: interelectronic repulsion, spin-orbit coupling, ligand field effect, and the Zeeman effect of an external magnetic field. The ligand field operator, reference to the 4-fold rotation axis for the angular part of the wave function assuming D 4h  symmetry, reads      Ĥ   lf   =    B   0    2     ∑   i = 1   N       C   0    2    ( i )   +    B   0    4     ∑   i = 1   N       C   0    4    ( i )   +    B   4    4     ∑   i = 1   N     (    C   4    4    ( i )  +    C   - 4    4    ( i )  )     All intracluster couplings are described by a Heisenberg-type exchange Hamiltonian, assuming an isosceles spin triangle:      Ĥ   ex   = - 2   J   1    (   Ŝ   1   ⋅   Ŝ   2   +   Ŝ   2   ⋅   Ŝ   3   )  - 2   J   2     Ŝ   1   ⋅   Ŝ   3     Intercluster interactions are taken into account by the molecular field approximation, expressed as χm -1 = χm'-1 - λmf where χm' denotes the molar susceptibility of a discrete {M3} spin cluster and λmf the molecular field parameter.

elements.content: The χm T value of 1 at T = 290 K (7.54 cm3 K mol–1) is smaller than the expected spin-only value of 13.1 cm3 K mol–1 for three isolated S = 5/2 centers (g iso = 2.0). This value and the low-field susceptibility data for compound 1 indicates predominate antiferromagnetic magnetic exchange interactions between the spin centers, mediated by the central μ3-O-bridge and the 4,4′-bpy linkers. A least-squares fit (Figure ) yields J 1 = −0.1 cm–1, J 2 = −27 cm–1, and λmf = −0.609 mol cm–3 (SQ = 1.2% for T ≥ 10 K). The deviations below 10 K are due to the 3D network character of the compound that is only approximated by the applied molecular field model. The exchange coupling constants deviate to a large degree, which is unexpected from a geometrical point of view but is a potential result of spin frustration, describing two centers that couple antiferromagnetically and interact very weakly with the third center. Both inter- and intracluster exchange interactions are antiferromagnetic as expected.

A least-squares fit (Figure ) yields J 1 = -0.1 cm-1, J 2 = -27 cm-1, and λmf = -0.609 mol cm-3 (SQ = 1.2% for T ≥ 10 K). The deviations below 10 K are due to the 3D network character of the compound that is only approximated by the applied molecular field model. The exchange coupling constants deviate to a large degree, which is unexpected from a geometrical point of view but is a potential result of spin frustration, describing two centers that couple antiferromagnetically and interact very weakly with the third center. Both inter- and intracluster exchange interactions are antiferromagnetic as expected.

elements.content: Temperature dependence of χm T for 1 (□) and 2 (○) at 0.1 T; solid lines, least-squares fits to the employed phenomenological models (see text). Inset, temperature dependence of the reciprocal susceptibility.

elements.content: The χm T value of 2 at T = 290 K (5.36 cm3 K mol–1 per {Fe2Co} unit) continually decreases with decreasing temperature until the magnetic moment increases again below 20 K (Figure ). This behavior can be explained by several factors: (1) contributions of the orbital momentum of CoII in {Fe2Co}, (2) intracluster (ferromagnetic) coupling in the {Fe2Co} triangular unit, and (3) intercluster (ferromagnetic) interactions between the {Fe2Co} units. In order to evaluate the latter two effects, we have to investigate the inter- and intracluster exchange coupling while simultaneously considering the single-ion effects. The local ligand field symmetry of the CoII center is approximated as D 4h , and the Fe­(III) centers are modeled as isotropic S = 5/2 systems (g iso = 2.0). A least-squares fit yields three independent ligand field parameters B 0 2 = −5500 cm–1, B 0 4 = 13500 cm–1, and B 4 4 = 10800 cm–1 for the Co­(II) center. The exchange interaction parameters are J 1 = +55 cm–1 (Fe–Co), J 2 = −122 cm–1 (Fe–Fe), and λmf = +1.163 mol cm–3 (SQ = 1.8% for T ≥ 10 K). The signs of the ligand field parameters conform to the expectation of the point-charge electrostatic model. The results exhibit a ferromagnetic interaction of the Co­(II) center with each Fe­(III) of the triangle structure. The Fe­(III) centers show strong antiferromagnetic exchange interactions. Moreover, the intercluster interactions are weak but ferromagnetic.

elements.content: The room temperature 57Fe Mössbauer spectra of 1 and 2, see Figure , are simple, somewhat asymmetric doublets. Detailed analysis of the data indicates that a significant improvement of the fits is achieved by taking into account slight preferential oriental and two spectral components. The reduced χ2 of the displayed final fits are 1.15 and 1.0, respectively. For the {Fe3}-based 3D network 1, the isomer shift relative to α-iron, δ, and quadrupole splitting, ΔE Q, of the components are δ(1) = 0.385(3) and δ(2) = 0.389(3) mm/s and ΔE Q (1) = ±0.56(1) mm/s and ΔE Q (2) = ±0.89(1) mm/s with 24% of the spectral area for the second component, and line widths Γ = 0.31(1) mm/s. For the {Fe2Co}-based 3D network 2, the isomer shift relative to α-iron, δ, and quadrupole splitting, ΔE Q, of the components are δ(1) = 0.391(4) and δ(2) = 0.35(1) mm/s and ΔE Q (1) = 0.99(1) mm/s and ΔE Q (2) = 0.63(2) mm/s with 35% of the spectral area for the second component, and line widths Γ = 0.36(1) mm/s.
elements.clean_text:
Mössbauer Spectroscopy

The room temperature 57Fe Mössbauer spectra of 1 and 2, see Figure , are simple, somewhat asymmetric doublets. Detailed analysis of the data indicates that a significant improvement of the fits is achieved by taking into account slight preferential oriental and two spectral components. The reduced χ2 of the displayed final fits are 1.15 and 1.0, respectively. For the {Fe3}-based 3D network 1, the isomer shift relative to α-iron, δ, and quadrupole splitting, ΔE Q, of the components are δ(1) = 0.385(3) and δ(2) = 0.389(3) mm/s and ΔE Q (1) = ±0.56(1) mm/s and ΔE Q (2) = ±0.89(1) mm/s with 24% of the spectral area for the second component, and line widths Γ = 0.31(1) mm/s. For the {Fe2Co}-based 3D network 2, the isomer shift relative to α-iron, δ, and quadrupole splitting, ΔE Q, of the components are δ(1) = 0.391(4) and δ(2) = 0.35(1) mm/s and ΔE Q (1) = 0.99(1) mm/s and ΔE Q (2) = 0.63(2) mm/s with 35% of the spectral area for the second component, and line widths Γ = 0.36(1) mm/s.

elements.content: 57Fe Mössbauer spectra of 1 at 295 K (top left) and 6 K (bottom) and of 2 at 295 K (top right). Two doublets were used to model the 295 K data, and three magnetic components were used to model the 6 K data, see text.
elements.clean_text: 6   57Fe Mössbauer spectra of 1 at 295 K (top left) and 6 K (bottom) and of 2 at 295 K (top right). Two doublets were used to model the 295 K data, and three magnetic components were used to model the 6 K data, see text.

elements.content: The low-temperature (6 K) spectrum for 1 indicates the appearance of a large hyperfine field related to absorption lines at ±8 mm/s. In total, three spectral components are necessary in order to achieve a satisfactory fit, one with a small static hyperfine field, one with a large static hyperfine field, and one with a fast relaxing large hyperfine field. As for the 295 K spectrum, here also a small amount of preferential orientation is required in the model. Although the modeling with three components might seem complicated, direct signs in the spectral shape indicate that this is required: a clear sextet is observed requiring a component with a static hyperfine field, the asymmetric broadened central part cannot be fitted with a paramagnetic doublet, in part due to the suppressed gap in the spectrum, thus requiring a small hyperfine field, and, finally, the wings in the central part, around −1 and +2 mm/s could not be fitted by any other component than one with a fast isotropically relaxing hyperfine field. In particular, it was not possible to fit the complete central part with a single relaxation component. Simplifying constraints were hence used in order to minimize the number of independent fitting parameters. As indicated by the room temperature spectrum, a single value for the isomer shift is an admissible approximation and a single overall value, fitted to δ = 0.495(4) mm/s, was used in order to simplify the fits. The first component with a small static hyperfine field, μ0 H hf = 0.72(4) T, corresponds to 25% of the spectral area, Γ = 0.40(4) mm/s, ΔE Q = −0.82(2) mm/s. For the two components with a large hyperfine field, it was possible to achieve a good overall fit with reduced χ2 of 1.25, with a single value for the line width, Γ = 0.68(5) mm/s, the field, μ0 H hf = 47.5(1) T, and the quadrupole splitting, ΔE Q = −0.60(6) mm/s. The first of these components, with the static field, corresponds to 25% of the spectral area, and an angle between the principal axis of the electric field gradient and the field, θ = 45°,of the second components corresponds to 50% of the spectral area and was modeled with a isotropic hyperfine field fluctuating at a frequency of 1000(150) MHz.

elements.content: With the parameters extracted from the Mössbauer spectra, a limited number of conclusions can be drawn. First, the combination of isomer shifts of 0.35–0.40 mm/s and quadrupole splittings of 0.5–1.0 mm/s observed in the 295 K spectra of sample 1 and 2 precludes the presence of high-spin Fe­(II) and is typical for high-spin Fe­(III), in line with the results of the magnetochemical analysis. Similar parameters, especially the isomer shift, have been observed for Fe­(III) in related pivalate trinuclear complexes at room temperature (δ = 0.35–0.45 mm/s) and low temperatures (δ = 0.55 mm/s) and are attributed to high-spin ferric iron in octahedral coordination. Second, further evidence for the identification as high-spin Fe­(III) comes from the larger (∼48 T) hyperfine field that develops at low temperature in sample 1. Third, the rather complex spectrum at low temperature is indicative of complex magnetism, likely originating in magnetic frustration, where parts of the Fe spins are static at 6 K but a large part is still rapidly fluctuating and another part exhibits a very small hyperfine field.

elements.content: Starting from hexanuclear pivalate cluster [Fe6O2(OH)2(O2CCMe3)12], two new cluster-based MOFs consisting of cationic homometallic μ-oxo trinuclear [Fe3O­(O2CCMe3)6]+ or neutral heterometallic μ-oxo trinuclear [Fe2CoO­(O2CCMe3)6] clusters bridged by different N,N′-donor ligands, 4,4′-bipyridine in case of 1 and 1,2′-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethylene and pyrazine in case of 2, into 3D networks of {[Fe3O­(O2CCMe3)6(4,4′-bpy)1.5]­(OH)·0.75­(CH2Cl2)·x(H2O)} n (1) and {[Fe2CoO­(O2CCMe3)6(bpe)0.5(pyz)]} n (2) were successfully synthesized in “one-pot” solvothermal reactions in dichloromethane. The exploitation of rigid or flexible ligands of different length for the formation of MOFs open up possibilities for the variation of framework topologies: a 6-fold interpenetrated network with rare (8,3)-c (etc) topology for 1 and a 3-fold interpenetrated network with a (10,3)-b (ths) topology for 2. The sorption behavior for N2 and CO2 were investigated; the interpenetration in both 1 and 2 effectively renders these compounds nonporous. Magnetic studies of 1 and 2 revealed the existence of antiferromagnetic intracluster Fe···Fe exchange interactions but also ferromagnetic Fe···Co and intercluster coupling in 2. The assembly and characterization of new cluster-based MOFs with less interpenetration between the sublattices is currently underway.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Starting from hexanuclear pivalate cluster [Fe6O2(OH)2(O2CCMe3)12], two new cluster-based MOFs consisting of cationic homometallic μ-oxo trinuclear [Fe3O(O2CCMe3)6]+ or neutral heterometallic μ-oxo trinuclear [Fe2CoO(O2CCMe3)6] clusters bridged by different N,N'-donor ligands, 4,4'-bipyridine in case of 1 and 1,2'-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene and pyrazine in case of 2, into 3D networks of {[Fe3O(O2CCMe3)6(4,4'-bpy)1.5](OH)⋅0.75(CH2Cl2)⋅x(H2O)} n  (1) and {[Fe2CoO(O2CCMe3)6(bpe)0.5(pyz)]} n  (2) were successfully synthesized in "one-pot" solvothermal reactions in dichloromethane. The exploitation of rigid or flexible ligands of different length for the formation of MOFs open up possibilities for the variation of framework topologies: a 6-fold interpenetrated network with rare (8,3)-c (etc) topology for 1 and a 3-fold interpenetrated network with a (10,3)-b (ths) topology for 2. The sorption behavior for N2 and CO2 were investigated; the interpenetration in both 1 and 2 effectively renders these compounds nonporous. Magnetic studies of 1 and 2 revealed the existence of antiferromagnetic intracluster Fe⋅⋅⋅Fe exchange interactions but also ferromagnetic Fe⋅⋅⋅Co and intercluster coupling in 2. The assembly and characterization of new cluster-based MOFs with less interpenetration between the sublattices is currently underway.

cln_elements.content:
Thermogravimetric analyses for the MOFs were performed in a nitrogen flux in the temperature range of 25–600 °C. The TGA data for 1 shows a first weight loss until 180 °C corresponding to the removal of 0.75 dichloromethane and eight water solvent molecules (obsd 10.5%, calcd 11.5%). On further heating, organic ligands (six pivalate and 4,4′-bipyridine) decompose in three weakly resolved steps with a total weight loss of 77.0% (calcd 74.3%). MOF 2 remains stable up to 200 °C, followed by the decomposition of metal–organic frameworks in three unidentified steps until ca. 560 °C to give the expected heterometallic oxides with a total weight loss of 84.2%.

N2 and CO2 uptake capacities of 1 and 2 were assessed by gas adsorption measurements at 1 bar. After activation, 1 can take up 39.5 cm3(STP) g–1 of N2 at 77 K, whereas 2 can take up 30.1 cm3(STP) g–1 of N2 at 77 K (Figures S8 and S9, ). CO2 adsorption capacities at 298 K (Figures S10 and S11, ) amount to 1.2 cm3(STP) g–1 for 1 and 2.5 cm3 (STP) g–1 for 2. Overall, these values are close to the measurement error limits and indicate no significant porosity.

The crystal structure of 1 displays a 6-fold interpenetration of networks, Figure b. Despite the high degree of interpenetration, the resulting framework still possesses porosity and reveals infinite channels along the c crystallographic axis, cylindrically shaped with a diameter of ca. 1 nm and rectangular rods of ca. 1.0 × 0.5 nm2 size, Figure . These channels are filled by hydroxide counteranions, water, and dichloromethane solvent molecules. Upon removal of neutral solvent molecules, the structure of 1 reveals a large total potential solvent area volume of 12744 Å3 (39.3%, yellow color in Figure S2, ) per unit cell volume of 32439.9 Å3, as calculated by PLATON. Because hydroxide counteranions and water molecules have not been reliably localized, we assume that each hydroxide anion, necessary for charge neutrality, occupies a volume of 40 Å3. The crystallization water content of 1, x ≈ 8, though not identified directly from the single-crystal structure, was consistently derived from both thermal and elemental analysis.

Compound 2, [Fe2CoO­(O2CCMe3)6(bpe)0.5(pyz)] n , crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c and exhibits a 3D network composed of trinuclear [FeIII 2CoIIO­(O2CCMe3)6] clusters linked by pyrazine (pyz), and 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethylene (bpe) linear spacer ligands. The atoms of the cluster moiety lie on general positions; thus all the metal atoms are symmetry-independent. Each cluster is connected with two coplanar clusters by centrosymmetric pyz and bpe ligands and one noncoplanar cluster via another pyz ligand. The latter resides on a 2-fold axis and is disordered over two symmetry related positions with equal probability. The dihedral angle between the planes through their Fe2CoO cores of adjacent 2-fold related cluster equals 71.8°. This couple of adjacent nonparallel clusters may be regarded as a four-connected unit with a nonplanar connectivity, Figure , but in contrast to 1, it is composed of symmetry related nodes and different spacer ligands, which differ in their length. The resulting network has an uniform uninodal (10,3)-b (ths) topology, Figure . The cluster···cluster separation through pyz ligands equals 10.899(4) and 10.902(4) Å for pairs of parallel and nonparallel clusters, respectively, and 17.254(3) Å through the bpe ligand, and corresponding Fe/Co···Fe/Co distances are 7.096(1), 7.142(1), and 13.603(1) Å, respectively. The crystal structure of 2 comprises 3-fold interpenetrated networks, which create voids with an individual volume of 191 Å3, Figure S3, . The total potential solvent area volume is 2204.1 Å3 (19.1%) per unit cell volume of 11547.4 Å3.

This couple of adjacent nonparallel clusters may be regarded as a four-connected unit with a nonplanar connectivity, Figure , but in contrast to 1, it is composed of symmetry related nodes and different spacer ligands, which differ in their length. The resulting network has an uniform uninodal (10,3)-b (ths) topology, Figure . The cluster⋅⋅⋅cluster separation through pyz ligands equals 10.899(4) and 10.902(4) Å for pairs of parallel and nonparallel clusters, respectively, and 17.254(3) Å through the bpe ligand, and corresponding Fe/Co⋅⋅⋅Fe/Co distances are 7.096(1), 7.142(1), and 13.603(1) Å, respectively. The crystal structure of 2 comprises 3-fold interpenetrated networks, which create voids with an individual volume of 191 Å3, Figure S3, . The total potential solvent area volume is 2204.1 Å3 (19.1%) per unit cell volume of 11547.4 Å3.
